sect1.title: Mental Status Examination
sect1.para: The mental status examination (MSE) mental status examination (MSE) is a structured assessment of the clinically relevant areas of a client’s behavioral, emotional, and cognitive functioning. By coalescing observations from these domains, the MSE paints a picture of the client at a given point in time and helps the clinician form a working hypothesis about a client’s psychiatric diagnosis/es and functioning functioning . A standardized approach and focused questions allow the clinician clinician to assess multiple domains domains —and ascertain patterns across domains domains —to best conceptualize and understand the client. Any indications of abnormality should be reported and described.

para.emphasis: The client was a 69-year-old, Spanish speaking, Hispanic white man who appeared younger than his stated age. He was of average weight and dressed appropriately in tailored slacks and a button-up shirt. Intact grooming and hygiene were noted, as evidenced by neatly trimmed hair and fingernails and a closely clipped beard. He was cooperative with his examiner and translator but responded in a very concise manner to the examiner’s questions without much elaboration. Over the course of the interview, he became more forthcoming and at times tearful. He evidenced an anxious affect, sitting with his hands clenched and often averting eye contact to stare at the floor.

A 42-year-old multiracial, nonbinary (pronouns: they/them) person presented 20 minutes late to their appointment, arriving via bus with their adult daughter. A lack of grooming and hygiene was evident. Mx. Jones was disheveled; their clothes appeared unwashed and stained, and their hair appeared unwashed and unbrushed. They left their sunglasses on during the interview and would rise frequently from the chair to walk around the room and mutter incomprehensibly. They had a notable body odor of stale cigarette smoke. Mx. Jones appeared apathetic and evidenced poor insight, responding to the examiner’s questions with phrases such as “I don’t know. She brought my here,” referring to their daughter.

sect1.para: Without knowing more about each client’s symptoms or problems, these brief examples begin to illustrate the unique presentations and potential difficulties experienced by each individual. Each vignette raises different clinical hypotheses and suggests different lines of inquiry during the interview.

Although individual observations may be important to consider in isolation, remember that the MSE MSE is only one component of a comprehensive examination and is most meaningful in the context of a thorough evaluation that includes a psychosocial history, review of psychiatric symptoms, and medical evaluation to inform a diagnosis and initial treatment plan (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ).

During an intake interview intake interview , the MSE offers the clinician’s initial insights into the client’s functioning and disorder severity compared to individuals from the same population or setting. In a treatment context, these impressions may evolve over time and with ongoing interactions.
